The director did a great job, it was a great movie, the cast was amazing, particularly the actor who played Dr. King, and it did an excellent job of capturing the problems of that time, the hatred and disdain and vilification that King's supporters faced (the scene where he is in jail and he notes that Malcolm X called him a sellout for being non-violent is particularly heartbreaking). But Oprah is an icon of narcicisstic consumerism, she has no place in a movie about the struggles of real people. Get celebrities out of human rights activism - I mean I would love it if they would contribute, but stop demanding their smug faces be front and centre. Helping people should not be about self-aggrandizement and King knew that. His moral commitment and humility is exactly why people worship him today even though he wouldn't have wanted that. "There's a lady we all know / Who shines a light and wants it shown."

Title: Selma Official Trailer #1 (2015) - Oprah Winfrey, Cuba Gooding Jr. Movie HD
Comment: This movie was outstanding! The acting was impeccable. I mean, David Oyelowo, Tim Roth, Oprah, Martin Sheen, Tom Wilkinson. Just an awesome cast. I do have to say though, that the way that they portrayed Gov. George Wallace was a little shotty. They nailed Wallace's annoyed stature but what they left out was that he was a FUMING racist. And yeah, Tim Roth did put his own southern/racist flair on the character, but before Wallace became "accepting" (Which I think is BS, just my own thought) of all people, he was a disgusting, bigoted man with a lot of problems. I just wish they told a little more of his story with the ways he really felt. Other than that, I thought this movie was brilliant. I advise everyone to go see it with an open mind. -J

Title: Selma Official Trailer #1 (2015) - Oprah Winfrey, Cuba Gooding Jr. Movie HD
Comment: I Just finished watching the movie. I really did enjoy it! It captured the struggle of the Selma to Montgomery March, so well. I actually heard sobbing during some scenes in the movie. The parts that were cinematic gold to me was when the riots started to occur and CBS capturing the whole thing. You see people at home crying and shocked in seeing innocent people getting beaten down and killed for no good reason. You feel like you were there sitting at home, hopelessly watching every single hit being hit on old and young bodies.  Caught in slow motion to see how horrible it was to be a black minority in the 1960s South side of selma Alabama . And also love the actor who played Dr, Martin Luther king. My first impression of him was... ''hmm he barely looks like him, pretty sure this movie is going to suck.'' I was DEAD wrong. That man knows how to act! He has the strong, yet peaceful voice same as MLK and even showed us it wasn't easy being in his shoes as well. What I got from the movie entirely is people always say you can't do something  just because of who you are. I watched this movie because MLK is a highly respectful role model to me as a young teen. There is always injustice and cruel things in the world.

Title: Selma Official Trailer #1 (2015) - Oprah Winfrey, Cuba Gooding Jr. Movie HD
Comment:
There is a great deal to admire about Selma. David Oyelowo's performance as Martin Luther King deserves all the plaudits it gets and the writing by Paul Webb is fantasic. Especially because they were not allowed to use the original speeches because Steven Spielberg owns the rights to them. 
It's very surprising that there has not been a big feature film about King before and i'm not totally convinced that Selma is the one that is going to do the great man justice. Perhaps that will eventually come from Spielberg ?
I loved the old footage shown at the end of the film.

I've now seen all the films nominated for best picture at this years Oscars and i'm still not sure what i like best. I loved Birdman and Theory Of Everything but the one that sticks in my head longest after i saw it is Boyhood but for me the best film wasn't even nominated and that is NightCrawler. 



7 out of 10

King has become a symbol of good, yet no one will discuss who he really was or what he really believed, because many of the same problems still fester under the surface, and it's considered impolite to note that the American government, particularly through the war on drugs, is STILL a borderline fascist instrument by which the powerful crush minorities and the poor. This movie portrayed King as a real human being with his flaws, facing an insurmountable struggle (which eventually killed him). Yet there is "glory" when "a man stands up and says enough is enough."

Comment:
I'm a white conservative and I approve this message:

Martin Luther King Jr. was an incredible man. He unified the nation and fought back against true injustice and racism. He did all of this through PEACEFUL gatherings, marches, and protests. The police had no right at all to attack the protesters because they were peacefully assembling. King didn't use this to gain power or to further any agenda. All he wanted was equal rights for all. He was a true civil rights activist who had a dream that people would not be judged by the color of their skin, but by the content of their character.

Fast forward to today and things aren't much better. People claiming to be civil rights activists such as Al Sharpton, Jesse James, and even Obama are inciting all of this racial violence in the name of Martin Luther King Jr and civil rights. People honor the man by exercising exactly what he fought against: racism on all sides. As an outlet for all of their hate and anger, they turn to violence and looting. In this case, the police have the right to intervene as the riots threaten the lives of the people around them. I'm not saying all black people are taking part in these riots, and I'm also not saying that all the people taking part are even black.

We cannot fight racism with more racism. A black person can be racist just as much as a white person can. Black lives matter, but we ignore the fact that white, latino, asian, and especially police lives also matter. King did not fight for special privileges for black people, he fought for equality for all races.

Title: Selma Official Trailer #1 (2015) - Oprah Winfrey, Cuba Gooding Jr. Movie HD
Comment: Huuuh....While some call this propaganda against white people, I just seen the movie and it IS NOT. If it was propaganda it wouldn't have included the tape of Martin with the prostitute, mentioned how other blacks stand by the prejudice in Martin's speech during a marcher's eulogy, and this movie gave credit to the WHITE AMERICANS WHO JOINED THE MOVEMENT. As well it shown that not all blacks agreed with Martin as well as his strategies used to make the movement affective, not as a "magical moral act against evil", but a serious political shift protesting the violence of Hate in our country of America. I can imagine that this wasn't as serious happen in rest of America, but it WAS a problem in the south. I even agree that some things are NOT the "white man's" fault. For example, not getting an education, getting a job of honest living of ANY KIND, or how there is not enough blacks in state/city offices. I'm not racist towards whites, hell, many of the friends I ever had were WHITE. Hatred in this movie doesn't exist just among Blacks being persecuted by whites, but in India now, Israel now, Nigeria now, Haiti now, and the worst thing we Americans can do is act like it didn't happen to us, because that would be disrespectful to people born generations yesterday who either died or came back mortified and/or injured to give us these freedoms today. There are actual rallies, documentaries on groups that sided with supremacy, so how is it that this is one sided propaganda? If you have never witness hatred like this, many envy you, but as one of the many African American citizens of the future who's rights were given with the price of various life scarring and persistence , DO NOT say this didn't happened, DO NOT say I'm a hypnotized monkey because I LEARN about the rest of the world and met other people while you sit in your bubble. I will NOT respond to you if you can't appeal to logic, if One can believe brave men gave us our freedoms 300 years ago, what makes these men any damn different? In revolutionary times, families were TORN, Benjamin Franklin's for example, between independence and loyalty to the crown. People TODAY are beaten and/or killed for there culture or any other difference. The idea of Blacks being separated from Whites in theory doesn't sound so bad until violence takes place. Whites were the political citizens since colonial times and it wasn't until the late 1880's that Black slaves were freed and considered citizens. Now think, of course people weren't going to adjust to Black people as citizens in communities and, to be fair, many Blacks at the time (and today) didn't help their cause either by hanging on to the past as an excuse for not achieving in life. So there were to sides, Whites claiming superiority with severe prejudice, and Blacks not seeking opportunity and blaming them for ALL of their own faults. Still though, Martin, despite his flaws, and many others stood up and strategically thought and followed for more opportunities deserved and to reveal man's eternal folly, Hate as well as demonstrating how Blacks do have power to get places, the "White man" is no excuse. This film serves a purpose for reminding people both the many who suffered for freedom, like the martyrs in times of Christ, and the opportunities we have today and how possible for us to have an honest living compared to yesterday. Maybe, with the wealth and resources my parents (who are from the 1960's) worked hard to give me, I can remind people this, because now it is easier than ever before in our country which, while it DEFINITELY has it's freedoms, still has woe to the people.

Title: Selma Official Trailer #1 (2015) - Oprah Winfrey, Cuba Gooding Jr. Movie HD
Comment: This looks like "the MLK movie we needed but not the MLK movie we deserved."  This seems like a movie that will probably be shown in a lot of classrooms...not because it's truly a monument of film but because it's the only MLK biopic available until something better comes along.  I totally understand the Academy's defense of the "snub".  A Best Picture nomination for an amateur director that could potentially win is hardly "being snubbed".  Strong material, but the direction, acting and cinematography seem "adequate" rather than "outstanding".  There are some historical figures that were just one of a kind and no one can capture their spirit right, but an American might have been able to channel the energy better than a British actor.

Title: Selma Official Trailer #1 (2015) - Oprah Winfrey, Cuba Gooding Jr. Movie HD
Comment:
This movie has a few inaccuracies-namely in real life, Hoover was not acting on LBJ's orders (he did this frequently, acting on his own) and LBJ historically actually encouraged MLK to do a Selma like demonstration because he knew it would give him the justification to push through the voting rights act. It also has the timing on a few events mixed up and MLK's motivations for missing the first selma march.

That aside, it's a fairly good movie as far as historical movies are concerned.

Comment: OMG this film is AWESOME! I just saw it, and I hope it wins big at the award shows. Initially, I didn't won't to see it--I was tired of period pieces--but I'm glad I saw it. It's not what it seems! It's NOT completely about Dr. King; it tells the story of brave white people (something that is often overlooked); it also humanizes Dr. King, instead of making him out to be a deity. It has the perfect balance of honesty, truth, facts, and humility. It's not a Black history film--it's an American history film. #A-MUST-SEE

ID4 ( Independence Day) came out to much applause and fanfare.

Comment: I'm a primary teacher from London, England and I recently taught the children in my class (9-10yrs old, all white) about MLK. It's not British History but it is still important. I then showed them a black and white image of some of the protests in Ferguson from this year. I asked them when they thought this was taken and they all thought 1960s. They were shocked to know that issues of race still divide so greatly. I think children have an innocence and purity about them that is often good to view the world through. Anyone moaning about this movie needs to wake up. It's an important story and still has lessons for today. If you find it so offensive, maybe you need to look inside your heart and think 'why?'

The film 'SELMA' is timely. Republicans now have control of both the Senate and the House. The country is moving to the RIGHT, politically.

As the nation advances slowly but surely toward a MAJORITY-MINORITY nation, GOP politicians at a STATE and FEDERAL level will revert back to what they know best and are very good at doing - craft and pass UNJUST LAWS to CURTAIL BLACK CIVIL AND VOTING RIGHTS to REMAIN in POWER as LONG as possible at the STATE and FEDERAL LEVEL.

Title: Selma Official Trailer #1 (2015) - Oprah Winfrey, Cuba Gooding Jr. Movie HD
Comment:
Four things you didn't know about Martin Luther King 

1. His name wasn't Martin Luther. It was Michael. It was decided Martin Luther had a more prominent ring to it, so he went by that. He never legally changed his name. To this day, he lived and died as Michael King. 

2. While working on his dissertation for his doctoral degree at Boston University, he heavily plagiarized from another author who had done research on a subject similar to King's. As academic committee later found that over half of King's work was plagiarized, yet would not revoke his doctrine. King was dead by this time, and the committee ruled that revoking the title would serve no purpose. It was also discovered that King's famous I HAVE A DREAM speech was also not his own. He stole it from a sermon by Archibald Carey, a popular black preacher in the 1950's. 

3. King was under FBI surveillance for several years (until he died) due to his ties with communist organizations throughout the country. King accepted money from the organizations to fund his movements. In return, King had to appoint communist leaders to run certain districts of his SCLC (Southern Christian Leadership Conference), who then could project their communist ideas to larger audiences. A federal judge in the 60's ruled that the FBI files on King links to communism to remain top-secret until 2027. Senator Jesse Helms appealed to the Supreme Court in 1983 to release the files, so the correct bill in the Senate to create the Martin Luther King Federal Holiday could be abolished. He was denied. 

4. One of King's closest friends, Rev. Ralph Abernathy, wrote a book in 1989 in which he talked about King's obsession with white prostitutes. King would often use church donations to have drunken sex parties, where he would hire two to three white prostitutes, occasionally beating them brutally. This has also been reported by the FBI agents who monitored King. King was married with four children. 

Martin Luther King Day. A day when this country will come to a screeching halt so we can have parades and memorials to honor this man, a man that most of the world views as a saint for his role in the civil rights movement. No other public holiday in the United States honors a single individual. Of all the great leaders in our Nation's history-none of them have their own holiday. All of our great war heroes share Memorial Day. All of our great presidents share President's Day. Yet king — a man who was a phony, a cheater, a traitor, and a sexual degenerate gets a day of his own.﻿

Title: Selma Official Trailer #1 (2015) - Oprah Winfrey, Cuba Gooding Jr. Movie HD
Comment: You have to take but 5 minutes scrolling down into the comments section of this video to see why this movie is still relevant. There are an equal amount of white AND black people who would like to forget this time period and move on as if it didn't exist, but can you understand the reasons why say women have the right to vote, without first understanding the suffragist movement? If you're a black person in America, you got where you are and the rights you have now because an entire line of people before you took both mental and physical beatings so you wouldn't have to and if you're a white person in America, hopefully this film will show you personally may not be those racists standing there with clubs, but those people did exist, this did happen, and ignoring it and pretending like this didn't happen won't make that period in history go away for you either. This moment in time was instrumental in changing a lot of the views whites held against blacks at the time, and as the movie also illustrates despite those prevailing views, there were many people, white and otherwise who stood with black people at the time and recognized the injustice right in front of them. Neither whites nor blacks can re-write history, but hopefully this film will show a new generation how deep a divide this country used to be in, and though much improved, how in many respects that divide is still there, but anyone can be an agent of change by learning from the mistakes of the past and learning to accept people as people.

Comment:
Before you say what the SELMA movie is about I suggest you see or read up on it.  This movie is more about voting rights and the rights the U.S. Constitution grants citizens and the protest it took for those rights to be extended, in my opinion (based on research).  If you see this a movie about race, you only see the surface shimmer.  The rights those people marched for are for all Americans.  You have Internet access do your own research. Ask yourself why would the state police stop a peaceful march from one city to another? Ask yourself why would people travel from miles to away, white, black, etc to join in a March which may result in your death? After you get those answers, ask yourself what would you be willing to march, fight, and die for, your country, your rights, your children?
Let us not be mindless robots, let us make our own minds up, do diligence people.  It's a movie about our country's past 50 years this coming March. #MarchOn

Title: Selma Official Trailer #1 (2015) - Oprah Winfrey, Cuba Gooding Jr. Movie HD
Comment:
Four things you didn't know about Martin Luther King 

1. His name wasn't Martin Luther. It was Michael. It was decided Martin Luther had a more prominent ring to it, so he went by that. He never legally changed his name. To this day, he lived and died as Michael King. 

2. While working on his dissertation for his doctoral degree at Boston University, he heavily plagiarized from another author who had done research on a subject similar to King's. As academic committee later found that over half of King's work was plagiarized, yet would not revoke his doctrine. King was dead by this time, and the committee ruled that revoking the title would serve no purpose. It was also discovered that King's famous I HAVE A DREAM speech was also not his own. He stole it from a sermon by Archibald Carey, a popular black preacher in the 1950's. 

3. King was under FBI surveillance for several years (until he died) due to his ties with communist organizations throughout the country. King accepted money from the organizations to fund his movements. In return, King had to appoint communist leaders to run certain districts of his SCLC (Southern Christian Leadership Conference), who then could project their communist ideas to larger audiences. A federal judge in the 60's ruled that the FBI files on King links to communism to remain top-secret until 2027. Senator Jesse Helms appealed to the Supreme Court in 1983 to release the files, so the correct bill in the Senate to create the Martin Luther King Federal Holiday could be abolished. He was denied. 

4. One of King's closest friends, Rev. Ralph Abernathy, wrote a book in 1989 in which he talked about King's obsession with white prostitutes. King would often use church donations to have drunken sex parties, where he would hire two to three white prostitutes, occasionally beating them brutally. This has also been reported by the FBI agents who monitored King. King was married with four children. 

Martin Luther King Day. A day when this country will come to a screeching halt so we can have parades and memorials to honor this man, a man that most of the world views as a saint for his role in the civil rights movement. No other public holiday in the United States honors a single individual. Of all the great leaders in our Nation's history-none of them have their own holiday. All of our great war heroes share Memorial Day. All of our great presidents share President's Day. Yet king — a man who was a phony, a cheater, a traitor, and a sexual degenerate gets a day of his own.

Title: Selma Official Trailer #1 (2015) - Oprah Winfrey, Cuba Gooding Jr. Movie HD
Comment:
"Another Civil Rights Movie?"
Okay. First of all, segregation is still a thing in Selma, Alabama. I have been there firsthand, and experienced it. I am going again in March, and this movie is such a big deal for me. Secondly, this movie is important to show what happened in Selma, pertaining to the events of Bloody Sunday, on the Edmund Pettus Bridge.
This movie is going to mean a lot to the people who live in Selma, who continue to fight for integration today, and to change the mindset of the entire town.
I have heard stories of people leave multi-billion dollar jobs just to move to Selma to fight segregation. Some people have had death threats, and had round the clock surveillance, because they just want to fight for integration. I have met the children of this town who are caught up in the middle, and who work together to show the town that it isn't just black and white. I have met people who were involved in the Bloody Sunday event, and heard their stories about how they didn't even know they were bleeding until someone pointed it out to them. And I have met people who remember this day like it was yesterday, who carry on the legacy of those who lost their lives.
So please, do not bash this movie because it's "just another Civil Rights movie;" this movie is very important to the people who can relate to this time, and to those who are still fighting in that town today.

Comment: Over my experience in school, there is no education about true Black History. I am not going to knock this movie because we do celebrate the holiday of this man and most of the kids today only think its a day they are out of school. I am glad that movies today are showing the truth of what happened so the younger generation can see/feel the trail that paved the way for black people/african american people/all minorities today. There are other minority movies out there that are not just about black history, but native american, mexican american and so on.  The truth is our America is more than just a one race nation.  I like seeing history movies and I like seeing movies like Django, Captain America Winter Soldier, or Equalizer.  Doesn't mean I like all one note type of movies. I am diverse and open minded by watching Gravity, Transcendence, and Hunger Games and other movies. (Hey, I'm a movie buff at heart) Yes, please put out more diverse and unique movies and Yes, to more diverse history oriented movies like how the hair dryer or stop light came about....  I'll watch!!! ;)
